work.p: There is a slim chance this manuscript might relate to the following line, in the poem that eventually would be titled "Song of Myself": "All sculpture and monuments and anything inscribed anywhere are tallied in you" (1855, p. 60).

titleStmt.title: Give us men
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
titleStmt.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: This scrap is pasted to a larger document along with another scrap, the reverse of which features prose lines that appear to be related to what became section 2 of "I Sing the Body Electric," first published untitled in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass. This scrap and the rest of the document were probably written shortly before or early in 1855.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman

This note is on a scrap that has been pasted onto a backing sheet to form a larger document.

metadata extracted and transformed from EAD file

body.ab: Give us men, fellows tall as who who was 5 ft 10 inches high, and nobly shaped and nimble and conquered all Asia and part of Europe in nine years, and wherever he went rected monuments to tell how he found the people.—If they were repulsive and brave he inscribed these monuments
